Well, maybe I----
Movin' in's mighty thirsty work. I usually sit out on my porch of an evening and pour a couple of beers over m'dinner. Come on over and join me, if you want.
Hey--they actually found the place!
Don't talk like an asshole even if you are just a bit of underdone potato or a blot of mustard.
Timmy Baterman. That was wrong.
I'll tell you where the ground is sour--the ground in my heart is sour. Let me tell you something else, Vic-baby: Wrong is wrong.
You don't understand--
The door must not be opened. The barrier must not be crossed.
Remember.
Leave me alone!
The power of this place is old and always restless. Sometimes the dead do more than speak. Remember, doc.
Please, I want to wake up. Leave me alone. It's not my fault you died; you were as good as dead when they brought you in--
The door must not be opened. The barrier must not be crossed. Don't go on, doc. No matter how much you feel you have to. There's more power here than you know.
I want to wake up. I want to wake up, that's all. I--
I'm sure.
Louis, are you sure?
I told you last night--this can be the start of patching things up with your folks. If something good doesn't come of Gage's death, I think I'll go crazy.
Oh Louis, I just don't know about this--
You better get going, hon.
You're doing fine.
I'm going to try to do better.
Yes, I guess I do.
Not by me, it isn't. I know how badly I acted, how unfair I was. It's just that I..you know.
That's forgotten.
I'm sorry I couldn't go with you to Missy's funeral. And that I blew up when we went to that silly animal graveyard.
That's not true. The subject scares me. Because of Zelda.
I thought maybe you did. I know you don't approve of the subject being raised--
I heard you tonight.
Good d--
I got eggs down here!
Getting there.
Oh, you're welcome. Only if some- thing should go wrong while he's under the gas--it's a one-in-a-thousand shot, but it happens--you explain to her.
Thank you, Louis.
Don't shilly-shally, Louis. Give the little girl her promise.
Well, honey...you know that...
And Church will be fine.
You'll be fine, Ellie. Now you can be excused. Go and wash your face.
I know what you just said. Ellie, clear your place.
I just said--
That's enough of that kind of talk!

According to what Mr. Crandall says, the road's a lot more dangerous than the operation. Church will be just the same. Well--almost the same--and we won't have to worry about him getting turned into catburgers by one of those damn Orinco trucks.
Don't be silly. Church is not going to die.
Do you think I didn't hear her tonight, crying as if her heart would break? Here she is thinking Church is going to die.
Jesus, Rachel, what's got into you?
It was that place. That creepy cemetery up in the woods. Whatever disease the kids in this town have got, I don't want Ellie to catch it.
She was a little over-excited, that's all. Poor kid.
She's finally asleep.
Extraordinarily morbid, maybe.
I think it's rather extraordinary.
It's beautiful!
My God!
Did you see his shirt?
---and you'll end up doing a free consultation on his arthritis or urinary problems and---
Well, I've got a million questions about the area, and---
You're not really going over to have a beer with that old guy, are you?
I don't have the slightest idea. When I saw the house, this field was under four feet of snow.
Yes--I know. This path, Louis? Where does it go?
The movers--
Yes--thanks. I'm Louis Creed.
Thank you. Thank you so much.
Jesus, the road!
Gage's gone!
Come on--let's parole 'em.
And Buckaroo Banzai.
Louis, the house is beautiful.
Let her go. It's cool.
Mr. Gibbs, organize a cleaning detail -- you and Cotton.  I want every inch of the Pearl spic-and- span and ship-shape!
Aye, aye, sir!
AnaMaria, trim the mainsail!
They'll be anchored on the lee side.  Haul your wind, and keep to the weather of the island --
How does he do that?
I will.
You'll get it back.  Or one better.
That boat is my livelihood!
Safe!  At Port Royal.  With the Royal Navy.
My dory.  The Jolly Mon.  Where is it?
AnaMaria!  Have you seen Gibbs?  I need to put together --
You stole my boat.
He didn't waste it.
Hah.  Ten years you carried that pistol, and you end up wasting your shot.
Quite, boy, or you'll lose your tongue.  Those as know me know I wouldn't cross my word, and bring down bad luck on the ship.  I agreed to set them free.  I didn't when ... nor where.
No!  You gave your word!
Eh?  You have my word, then -- on the Good Book, I do swear, and the Lord spare my worthless soul.
You must swear by the Holy Bible.
And Jack.  And the crew.  Free and unharmed.  If you agree ... then ... I will remain with you.
We got that part.  Anything else?
Elizabeth goes free!
Enough of that!  Name your terms.
You can't.  I can.
You've got one shot -- and we can't die.
She.  Goes.  Free.
What's in your head, boy?
Or you could surrender.
So what now, Jack Sparrow?  Are we to be two immortals, locked in epic battle until the trumpets of Judgement Day?
Remarkable how often those two traits coincide.
Just so you know, Jack -- I don't think you're that clever.  I think you're a fool.  A mortal fool.
Aye, for us there is.
There's ... another exit?
Men!  Are you up for it?
Now, you can take care of the Dauntless, right?

Aye.  See, after you're done with the Royal Navy, you'll have a bit of a problem: the H.M.S. Dauntless. There you'll be, with two lovely ships on your hands, and what to do?  Of course you'll decide you deserve the bigger one, and who's to argue?  The Dauntless a first- rate ship-of-line, and with it, you can rule the seas.  But if you're Captain of the Dauntless, who's left for the Black Pearl?
That so?
The situation has changed.
I can't help wondering, Jack, why you're being so helpful and all? Last time you did that, it didn't end well for you.
Like after you've killed ... Every ... Last ... One ... of Norrington's men.
What're you suggesting?
You've no hope of surviving Norrington's attack ... that is, if you're mortal.
Because, right about now, the H.M.S. Dauntless is lying in wait in the harbor.
Why don't I want to do this?
All right then.
No, I really think I do.
That's fair.
You can go to your grave not knowing.
So how did you get off that island, anyway?
The last time you do this, you left me a pistol, with one shot.
You'd best take a swim, Jack.
Someone needs to cut these bonds, then.
Now, Jack.  That reef is less than a league distant.  It's a square deal all around, and you can't hope for better.
It's pure evil to make a Captain walk the plank of his own ship, twice in one lifetime.  No good can come of it.
Bosun!  Set up Mr. Sparrow's quarters, nice and fine ... in the brig.  Meaning no disrespect, of course.
I'll watch my back.
That fool woman took it.  You be careful around her, Jack -- she's pretty enough, she'll steal your heart -- but pure evil inside.
What -- you don't have the medallion?
You're playing this as close to the edge as any man, I'll give you that.  We might just have to sign articles, you and I.  Jack, you're a pirate at heart, that's certain.
See, that's where we're different. I trust you ... to do what it takes to get what you want.
Jack, I don't trust you, and that's a fact.  Never trust a smiling man, you can lay to that.
Track you down and --
Let's say I tell you the wrong person.  What would you do?
You're setting me up for a double cross, you with the ship, and me with nothing more than your word!
Wait as long as you like.
Blast you!  I'll throw you in prison.
You left me on a desert island -- what worse can you do?
I'll torture it out of you.
You see, I've got this honest streak in me -- in its own way, a sort of curse.  Oh, and there's the fact that you have no choice.
I'm supposed to ... trust you?
That's right.
That's your offer?  You, sailing away nice and pretty with the Black Pearl, and all I have is a name?
You give me the Pearl.  Then I tell you who you need.
The Pearl?  Oh, that's fine.  And just how do you expect this to work?
Simple.  I have something you won't more than anything.  The way to free you from the curse of the treasure.  You have something I want -- more than anything.
Allow me the humor of listening to your terms.
No you won't.
Say the name, or I slit your throat.
I know whose blood you need, to end the curse.
No.  But him I believe.  He us genuinely angry.
Do you believe him?
I guess there is a reason to fret.
Turner blood doesn't flow pure in his veins.  Best play it safe, and spill it all.
No reason to fret.  It's just a prick of the finger and a few drops of blood.
By the powers, you're right!  Where's Jack's pistol?  Who's got it?  Bring it forward!
That's proper, sir, according to the code.
And he's got Old Bill's courage. A curse on him, and you!
Looks like your back to having nothing to offer.
Now.  No, don't kill him.
Now?
Will -- you can't trust him.
Agreed.  You have my word, as a gentleman of fortune --
Aye.  And not a bit of it any use to us, only hoarded.  But it will drive us no longer.
The curse drove you to gather this?
It's a piece of the treasure of Isla de Muerta.
It's a pirate medallion.
Do you not know what this is, then?
Would that I could.
Then why aren't you eating?
Oh, there would be no sense in killing you, Miss Turner.
Now, none of that.  Please dig in.
Dare I ask the fate of it previous owner?
Maid or not, it fits you.
It's you who invoked the parlay! Believe me, Miss, you'd best hand it over, now ... or these be the last friendly words you'll hear!
Can I trust you?
No, no, nothing like that.  Very well.  You hand that over, we'll put your town to our rudder and ne'er return.
Of course.  I didn't steal it, if that's what you mean.
And how does a maid come to own a trinket such as that?  A family heirloom, perhaps?
Thank you, sir.
You've got sand, for a maid.
Elizabeth --  Turner.  I'm a maid in the governor's household.
You have a name, missy?
Did you, now?
Because it's what you're searching for.  You've been searching for it for years.  I recognize this ship. I saw it eight years ago, when we made the crossing from England.
My holds are bursting with swag. That bit of shine matters to me ... Why?
I'll drop it!
Very well.
I am disinclined to acquiesce to your request.  Means 'No.'
I want you to leave.  And never come back.
There was a lot of long words in there, miss, and we're not but humble pirates.  What is it you want?
Captain Barbossa ... I have come to negotiate the cessation of hostilities against Port Royal.
My apologies, miss.  As you were saying, before you were so rudely interrupted?
Well, I am not going to stay hidden in some cabin, or I suppose it's going to be heaving bosoms and bare for the remainder of the voyage!
That would hardly be proper.
Then I can wear men's clothing.
You may seclude yourself in my cabin.  I'm afraid we do not have any ladies' clothing aboard.
I know where your heart truly lies.
What?
Elizabeth, I hereby withdraw my proposal.
Not as a condition -- a request.
I am to understand that you will accept my marriage proposal on the condition I rescue Mr. Turner?
Commodore, I beg you -- please do this ... for me.  As a wedding gift.
Commodore, please!
Your father is frantic with worry. Our mission was to rescue you and return home.  That is what we shall do.  Mr. Turner's fate is regrettable.  But so was his decision to engage in piracy.
No.  The pirates have taken Will --
He can locate Isla de Muerta -- but I doubt he'll be willing to help us from the brig.
You're speaking up for him again?
Commodore, you can't do that!
Elizabeth, I'm relieved you're safe.  Clap him in irons.  And behind his back this time.
Yes, I'm all right, I'm fine!  Go capture him.
On his heels!  Gillette, bring a squad down from the fort!  Elizabeth, are you --
One good deed is not enough to redeem a man of a lifetime of wickedness.
Commodore, I must protest.  Pirate or not, this man saved my life.
I'm a bit nervous, myself --
I can't breathe.

I apologize if I seem forward -- but I must speak my mind.  This promotion confirms that I have accomplished the goals I set for myself in my career.  But it also casts into sharp relief that which I have not achieved.  The thing all men most require: a marriage to a fine woman.  You have become a fine woman, Elizabeth.
Very good.
His name is Will Turner -- that's all I found out.
Did he speak?
Fetch a hook -- haul him out of there!
Boy overboard!
Man overboard!

Think again, Miss Swann. Vile and dissolute creatures, the lot of them. I intend to see to it that any man who sails under a pirate flag, or wears a pirate brand, gets what he deserves: a short drop and a sudden stop.
I think it would be rather exciting to meet a pirate.
About the day we met. Do you remember?
Elizabeth, this is hardly appropriate --
Women in London must have learned to not breathe.
I'm told that dress is the very latest fashion in London.
Difficult ... to say.
Or, rather, Commodore Norrington ... a fine gentleman, don't you think?  He fancies you, you know.
I knew it.
Captain Norrington's promotion ceremony.
Ceremony?
Although ... I did think you could wear it to the ceremony today.
Is an occasion necessary for a father to dote upon his daughter with gifts?
It's -- beautiful. May I inquire as to the occasion?
Yes -- yes.
Elizabeth? Is everything all right? Are you decent?
Yes, father.
And that's what concerns me. Elizabeth, we will be landing in Port Royal soon, and beginning our new lives. Wouldn't it be wonderful if we comport ourselves as befits our class and station?
Actually, I find it all fascinating.
He said you say that!  He also said if that be the case, you'll be dining with the crew, and you'll be naked.
Tell the captain that I am disinclined to acquiesce to his request.
You'll be dining with the Captain, and he requests you wear this.
It would appear, so do you.
If an adversary demands parlay, you can do them no harm until the parlay is complete.
I know the code.
Parlay!  I invoke the right of parlay!  According to the Code of the Brethern, set down by the pirates Morgan and Bartholomew, you must take me to your Captain!
What?
-- but that was not a proper kiss.
It doesn't!
Elizabeth, I think it doesn't matter that we are of a different class --
There.  And don't you dare tell me that wasn't a proper kiss!
I guess you can never truly know someone else's heart.
I can't believe he would make such a sacrifice for us.
-- then we never would have met.
If I had known --
To keep it away from them?  No pirate would sail to London, for fear of Execution Dock.
Why would my father send this to me?
Truthfully -- you were a bit late.
I'm glad we got here in time.
At least once more, Miss Swann. As always.
Will, how many times must I ask you to call me 'Elizabeth'?
I could never forget it, Miss Swann.
What's your plan?
I have a plan.  If it succeeds, then any battle will be decidedly brief ... and one-sided.
These men will be facing an enemy that seemingly cannot be killed.
Exactly.
He might delay the rescue ... and that would be too late.
Nor did you, I noticed.
You didn't tell Commodore Norrington everything.
Exactly.
You -- you burned up the island, for a one-time chance at being spotted?

That signal is over a thousand feet high, which means it can be seen for two hundred leagues in every direction.  The entire Royal Navy is out to sea looking for me -- do you think there is even a chance they could miss it?
One, because it is a vile drink that turns even the most respectable men into scoundrels. Two --
Why?
Yes, the rum is gone.
What are you doing?  You've burned our food, the shade -- the rum!
To the Black Pearl.
To freedom.
We've got a few bottles left ... and we've yet to tap the kegs.
Mr. Sparrow!  I'm not sure I've had enough rum to allow that kind of talk.
Ah, well ... the company is better than last time.  And the scenery has definitely improved.
Jack, it must be so terrible for you, to be trapped here on this island, all over again.
You'll be positively the most fearsome pirates to sail the Spanish Main.
When I get the Black Pearl back, I'm going to teach it to the whole crew, and we'll sing it all the time!
More to drink!
Well, perhaps ... with a bit more to drink, I might ...
Now I must hear this song.  An authentic pirate song.  Have at it.
That was before I met one, of course.
Oh, no ... it's silly.  Back in England we didn't know a thing about pirates, really.  They seemed so romantic and daring --
I know a lot of songs about pirates, but none I'd teach a child.  Let's hear it.
Nothing ... it's nothing.  Just ... I'm reminded of a song I learned as a child.  A song about pirates.
What?  What was that?  Something funny, Miss Swann? Share, please.
Drink up me hearties, yo ho ...
Not when you can drink instead, at least.
Don't be thinking I'm happy about this, Elizabeth.  But I see no use in wailing and gnashing my teeth over that which I can do nothing about.
You're right.  Here's luck to you, Will Turner.
A month?  Will doesn't have a month!  We've got to do something to help him!

You should look at our contretemps this way: we've got shade trees, thank the Lord.  We've got some food on the trees, thank the Lord again.  And we've got rum, praise the Lord.  We can stay alive a month, maybe more.  Keep a weather eye open for passing ships, and our chances are fair.
Welcome to the Caribbean, love.
So that's it?  That's the secret grand adventure of the infamous Jack Sparrow?  You spent three days on the beach drinking rum?

Last time, I was here a grand total of three days.  Last time, the rumrunners who used this island as a cache came by, and I bartered passage off.  But from the looks of this, they've been out of business, and so that won't be happening again.  We probably have your friend Norrington to thank for that.
But ... you did it before!  Last time --
It won't.  It won't, and so we won't.
What?  What's wrong?  How will this help us get off the island?
Don't be thinking I'm not already working on it.
Captain Sparrow!  We have to get off this island -- immediately!
The trees are taller.
Has it changed since the last time you were here?
No.  This won't work.  I'll stay behind, and fight them. You go on.
Come on!
No, I'm -- rescuing you.
You're in league with Barbossa!
Me!
You?!
I saved your life; now you've saved mine.  We're square.
You are despicable.
Miss Swann, if you'll be so kind?
Miss Swann.
Ah, that's a dark and unpleasant tale, best left untold.
How did you get off the island?
We're catching up!
What's in your head to put you in such a fine mood?
She can hold a bit longer.
We'd best drop canvas, sir!
That he is.
Kid's a bit of a stick, isn't he?
And you've got that, have you?
Not if the fool has something Barbossa wants.  Something he needs.
A fool's errand.
Aye, and that's why I know where it's going to be, and that's why I know what Barbossa is up to.  All I need is a crew.
Jack, it's a fool's errand: You've heard the tales they tell about the Pearl.
I'm going after the Black Pearl. I know where it's going to be, and I'm going to take it.
Say again?
Now where, I wonder, would they have gotten that idea?
Oh, there's a hard tale, Jack. Most of the decent pirates in town won't sail with you -- seem to think you're a jinx.
First -- have you found me a crew?
Make it last, then.  Now, what's the nature of this venture of yours?
Aye, that'll about do it.
Well, fortunately, I know how to counter it.  The man who did the waking buys the man who was sleeping a drink, and the man who was sleeping it drinks it while listening to a proposition.
Curse you for breathing, you slack- jawed idiot.  Mother's love, Jack, you know better than to wake a man when he's sleeping.  It's bad luck!
Will -- it'll go worse for us -- for Elizabeth, especially -- if we fight.
We can at least fight -- we might be able to kill a few--
That we are.
We're not going to just surrender!
It's a signal.  If we resist, it won't just be death.  There'll be torture as well.
How did he get off the island?
Jack gave hisself up for the sake of his loyal crew.  He was marooned on an island, left there to die.

Ah -- he's learned, then.  Plays things more close to the vest. See, Jack was a cartographer, back in Old England.  Somehow he came by the money to commission the Pearl. Hired himself a crew, promised each man an equal share.  So, they're forty days out, and the First Mate says, everything's an equal share, that should mean the location of the island, too.  So Jack gave up the bearings.  That night, there was a mutiny.
What?  He never told me that.
I'll tell lee.  Now, Jack Sparrow has an honest streak in him, and that's where the whole problem starts.  This was when he was Captain of the Black Pearl --
Really?  So ... what's the story on the pistol?
Now, lad, just because it don't point north don't mean it don't work.  That compass gives bearings to the Isla de Muerta, wherever it may lay.
How do we expect to find an island no one can find -- with a compass that doesn't work?
I know.  That was for the smell.
Blast it, I'm already awake!
I don't think that will be necessary.
Sir!  Shall I break out the cannons?
Wait for my order -- what the blazes is that?
All the men in place, sir.  Ready to fire.
Better to see it at the bottom of the sea than in the hands of a pirate.
Hands!  Come about!  Jackets off the cannons!  We are to fire on our own ship?
We need only to come about, to put them in range of the long nines.
The wind is quarter from astern ... by the time we're underway, we'll never catch them.
Raise the sails.
As likely as not.  Will, short up the anchor, we've got ourselves a ship!
Agreed.  You have the momentary advantage, sir.  But I will see you smile from the yard arm, sir.
Fine by me.  We brought you a nice little boat, so you can all get back to shore, safe and sound.
Sir, I'll not see any of my men killed or wounded in this foolish enterprise.
We'll see about that.
You understand this ship cannot be crewed by only two men.  You'll never make it out of the bay.
Dead serious.
I said, no lies.
None?  Very well.  You rumbled me. I confess: I intend to commandeer one of these ships, pick up a crew in Tortuga, and go on the account, do a little honest pirating.
Smith.
What's your name?
That so?  I've heard of one, supposed to be fast, neigh uncatchable ... the Black Pearl?
Oh, the Dauntless is the power in these waters, true enough -- but there's no ship that can match the Interceptor for speed.
That's a fine goal, I'm sure ... But it seems to me a ship like that --  -- makes this one here just a wee superflous.
This must be some important boat.
No ... somone has to make sure this dock stays off-limits to civilians.
Some sort of to-do up at the fort, eh?  You two weren't invited?
Sorry, I didn't know.
This dock is off-limits to civilians.
I'll slip in, talk them into to come out, and you'll be free to blow holy high heaven the whole lot of them.
I'll be at the wheel myself.
That chart I drew up'll get you past the reefs.  If you're steersman's good enough, that is.
I knew you'd listen to reason!
Nothing I wouldn't be please to be rid of.
They left me stranded.  Twice. What have you got to lose?
You would do that?
Funny, I was thinking along those lines.  How about you let me go in alone, and while you're setting up an ambush, I'll trick the pirates out to you.
I don't like the situation, Mister Sparrow.  The island is riddled with caves.  I will not put my men at a disadvantage.
By remembering that I serve others, not only myself.
Norrington, think about it ... the Black Pearl, its captain and crew ... the last pirate threat in the Caribbean.  How can you pass that up?
We are bound for Port Royal, not Isla de Muerta.
We had time to get to know each other.
Indeed.
But it seems to be enough to condemn him.
Ah, but you have heard of me.
Taking stock: you've got a pistol with only one shot, a compass that doesn't point north ... and no ship.  You are without a doubt the worst pirate I have ever heard of.
Captain Jack Sparrow.  If you please.
Well, well... Jack Sparrow, isn't it?

The worst.  On the other hand, maybe I'm a man who can't pass up a chance for revenge against the black-hearted bastard who stole my ship and left me to die in the middle of the ocean -- twice! -- and who knows how to get what he wants.  Now that's a great pirate.
Well, you're the worst pirate I've ever heard of.  You're a man who can be trusted, who can be counted on, and who can't betray his friends.  What kind of pirate is that?
-- and its guns and crew will cut you and your men to pieces the moment you step outside these caves.
Jack!
It's the right way.
Are you certain this is the right way?
Don't talk.  These caves magnify sound.  Just follow me.
Jack!
Do you have any idea where you're going?
My name is Will Turner, the son of Bootstrap Bill Turner.  His blood runs in my veins.  You need my blood.  And on my word I will pull this trigger, and sink all the way down to Davy Jones' Locker!
Will -- don't do anything stupid! Don't say anything stupid --
I'm sure.  When you've led the kind of life that I have, there are debts that must be paid.  Maybe I can balance the scales a little.
Are you sure?  Jack -- this is not something you have to do.
Go to the opposite end of the island, and signal the ship.  I'll keep 'em busy.
I'll lead them away.
No.
This way!
Miss Swann!  We're here to rescue you!  It's going badly!
On whether the stories are all true.  If they are, that's a waterfall that spills over at high tide, with a short drop to an underground lagoon.  If not --
On what?
Depends.
What's that?
Barbossa.
But I survived.  And I still have that single shot.  It's meant for one man.  My mutinous first mate--

The pistol.  When a pirate is marooned, Will, he's given a pistol with a single shot.  No good for hunting, or surviving, really.  But after three weeks of starvation and thrist -- the option of that pistol begins to look good.
Wait -- what about the pistol?
These are the only ones worth having.  And we're going to need them --
Shut up, before you lose them all!
Don't worry.  I've already got a Quartermaster -- there!
Just do it quickly.
Oh -- did I forget to mention that?
Tortuga?
Then that's not much incentive for me to fight fair, is it?
You didn't beat me.  You ignored the rule of engagement.  In a fair fight, I'd kill you.
Put it away, Will.  It's not worth getting beat again.
My father -- was not -- a pirate!
Sure -- because he could always go pirating.
My father did not think of my mother -- his family -- as a burden.

You think your father is the only man who ever lived the Glasgow life, telling folk one thing, and then going off to do another? There's quite a few who come here, hoping to amass enough swag to ease the burdens of respectable life. And they're all 'merchant marines.'
He was a merchant marine!  He was a respectable man who obeyed the law, and followed the rules--
Figured you wouldn't want to hear it.
It's not true my father was a pirate.
I swear, you look just like him.
That's not true.
Good man.  Good pirate.  And clever -- I never met anyone with as clever a mind and hands as him. When you were puzzling out that cell door, it was like seeing his twin.
'Bootstrap?'
I knew him.  Probably one of the few he knew him as William Turner. Most everyone just called him Bill, or 'Bootstrap' Bill.
My father.  William Turner?
Is that so?
I worked passage from England as a cabin boy.  After my mother passed, I came out here ... looking for my father.
For a man whose made an industry of avoiding boats, you're a quick study.
Aye!  Avast!
Everybody stay calm.  We're taking over the ship!
Remarkable how often those two traits coincide.
This is either crazy, or brilliant.
So's breaking a man out of jail. Face it, Will: you may say you'll never be a pirate, but you're off to a rip-roaring start.  My advice -- smile and enjoy it.
It's still against the law.
Commandeer.  We're going to commandeer a ship.  Nautical term.
We're going to steal a ship?  That ship?
No worries there.  She's far more likely to rot out from under us.
I haven't set foot off dry land since I was twelve, when the ship I was on exploded.  It's been a sound policy.
Come aboard.
Good.
I'd die for her.
My business, Will.  As for your business -- one question, or there's no use going.  This girl -- what does she mean to you?  How far are you willing to go to save her?
Why are brothering with that?
We need to go!
Not without my effects.
Agreed!
Agreed.
I helped build these cells.  Those are hook-and-ring hinges.  The proper application of strength, the door'll lift free.  Just calls for the right lever and fulcrum ...
How?  The key's run off.
I can get you out of here.
So it is that you found a girl. Well, if you're intending to brave all and hasten to her rescue and so win fair lady's heart, you'll have to do it alone.  I see no profit in it for me.
Never.  They took Miss Swann.
And you want to turn pirate yourself?
Because you're a pirate.
Why ask me?
The ship's real enough.  So its anchorage must be a real place. Where is it?
Surely you've heard the stories? The Black Pearl sails from the dreaded Isla de Mureta ... an island that cannot be found -- except by those who already know where it is.
Where does it make berth?
Somewhat.
Are you familiar with that ship? The Black Pearl?
No.  I can not just step aside and let you escape.
Move!
No.
Move away.
Pirate.
You cheated.
You need to find yourself a girl.  Or maybe the reason you practice three hours a day is you've found one -- but can't get her?
I do.  And I practice with them. At least three hours a day.
Who makes all these?
Only a little.
You threatened Miss Swann.
Do you think this is wise, boy? Crossing blades with a pirate?
Ah.  Then it would be a shame to put a black mark on your record.  So if you'll excuse me ...
I've made a point of avoiding familiarity with pirates.
You look familiar ... Have I ever threatened you before?
Still --
Mentioned it, is more what he did.
That Jack Sparrow ... he talked about the Black Pearl.
If he were telling truth he wouldn't have told us.
He may be.
He's not telling the truth.
I think he's telling the truth.
And no lies!
What's your business in Port Royal, 'Mr. Smith'?
Like I said, there's no real ship as can match -- Hey!

Oh, and no ship that's not crewed by the damned and captained by a man so evil that hell itself spat him back out could possibly have black sails and therefore couldn't possibly be any ship other than the Black Pearl.  Is that what you're saying?
But I've seen a ship with black sails.
No.
You've seen a ship with black sails that's crewed by the damned and captained by a man so evil that hell itself spat him back out?
Yes, I have.
You haven't seen it.
Yes.
You've seen the Black Pearl?
Yes.
You've seen it?
Yes it is.  I've seen it.
No, it's not.
The Black Pearl is a real ship.
There's no *real* ship as can match the Interceptor.
Dammit, man, it appears someone is stealing your ship!
Please.
But --
A moment.
Commodore --
Bleak.  Very bleak.
Well, she had a very taxing day... Ghastly weather tonight.
No.  She hasn't.
Has my daughter given you an answer yet?
An explosion in the powder magazine. Merchant vessels run heavily armed.
What happened here?
Where did he come from?
He's still breathing.
My apologies, Governor.
Captain Norrington... I appreciate your fervor, but I am concerned about the effect this subject will have on my daughter.
No.  The captain of the containment crew is closing down the main lab. He says the area has got to be evacuated.
Have you found Dr. Bright?
Dr. Argon, everything's starting to come apart here.  You hired me to take care of these matters of security and I am trying, but elements are making my job impossible.
Dr. Bright has escaped.
Speak.
Look, I don't mean to rain on everyone's ascension here, but we got a little problem.
You got it, Dr. Argon.
Mr. Sim, when you do locate him.  Do not scare him off again.  Just watch him.  I think you can handle that. Right, Mr. Sim?
Until he's done.
How long do you leave him in there?
A light mixture of oxygen, dioxide, and sodium pentothal.  He'll sleep, that's all.
What did you use?
Do?  Well, I suppose that depends on you.
What are you going to do to him?
Susan, I sense you are having difficulty understanding the situation you are presently in.  I ask that you keep in mind that I am ready to reduce an entire city to gelatin to get what I want.
I swear to you, Argon, if you don't stop the meltdown that nanobot will be the last one I ever build.

I look behind us, I look to the past, to a world steeped in rot and decay.  I think of the Acropolis in another century reduced to little more than dust.  I see the faces of Rushmore eventually losing all distinction, and then I look at this...
How do you know we're not heading in the wrong direction?
This is our world, Susan, and once you realize that, you will understand that the only place our path can end is on the throne of heaven.  Science is the quest for divine perfection.
Do you know what I see?  I see man making his own clouds.  I see man coloring his own sky, and like this garden it is a site that makes my heart sing.
Pollution?

I ask you what is the purpose of science?  What is the point of all our relentless exploration, investigation and experimentation? It is to understand a single physical phenomenon, or to understand them all?  To cure one disease, or to cure every disease? If science is simply a means, what then is the end?
I suppose you are going to tell me where it is going.

I brought you up here, Dr. Bright, because I want you to understand that we are on the path.  The only difference is that you are walking with your head down, afraid to look up, to see where the path is going.
Does that mean Oppenheimer loved the atomic bomb?
We will always love most that which we create.  Don't you agree, Susan?
You'll forgive me but all the excitement has left me extremely parched.  Poppy?
No, thank you.
Something to drink, Dr. Bright?
Come with me, Susan.  I want to show you something.
You can't mean that.
To be brutally honest with you, Susan, as long as the nanobot does to me what it did to that idiot O'Brien, I don't give a rat's ass about what happens after that.
But in another twenty-four hours the core meltdown will be beyond the stabilization period.  There will be no way to stop it.
Dr. Bright, I don't have to do anything.
No.
Mr. Sim I want you to return to Dr. Bright's.  I believe she is hiding something of ours there.
You don't have to give it to us because Dr. Nebbleman can just cut it out of him.
If you think I would ever give you the nanobot after this, you are deluding yourself.
Not anymore, Mr. O'Brien.  The nanobot has changed that.
Dr. Argon, I demand an explanation.
Wheelchair accessible.
That's right.  And making me was the biggest mistake you ever made!
You can't do this!  You owe me, O'Brien.  I made you plastic!  I made you!
Yeah, I'm going to finish what you started --
Please, O'Brien, don't do this to me!  I'll give you anything you want!
You think you can use me to stop the meltdown.
You mean besides kicking your ass?!
I know what you're doing.
The only history I'm gonna write is your obituary!
It remains to be seen who is the good guy and who is the bad guy. History is written by the victor.
Oh no.  You're not like me.  In fact, I'm betting you're the same greedy, remorseless, egomaniacal bad guy you always were.
As you can see I am a new man, just like you.
Ain't it.
How apropos.
Maybe you should, but you can't.
I should kill you right now for what you did to me!
You egomaniacs make me laugh. Nature's going to bury you like she buries everyone else.

The body is just another part of nature and ever since we gave up trees for central air, there has been nothing sacred about nature. Nature is the enemy, Mr. O'Brien, and science is our greatest weapon against her.
You're lacking a few things too: ethics, morals, common decency and, oh yeah, deodorant.
Poison?  I'm surprised at you.  You lack vision, Mr. O'Brien.
Wow, that is one moving story.  Take it easy on my heart strings.  Now I really feel guilty complaining about you shooting me up with your poison.
... plastic.

I can explain it.  Attempted murder wasn't enough for him.  He wants to add kidnapping to the charges.
Not that.

Did you feel that?
Poppy, this is not the time!
If you loved me like I loved you?
Poppy, please --
What I asked you earlier?

I was wondering if you'd finished considering?
I'm so excited, Icarus.
It will be an ascension.
Okay, arms up, lean forward.
This is what my entire life has been directed at, this moment, this threshold.
Oh yes, Icky.  I can feel it.
Can you feel it, Poppy?  The presence of the moment?  Can you feel the weight of its significance?
If you honestly trust me, then you'll have to trust me.
Consideration?
I promise, my dear, I will give the matter some consideration.
Icarus?
Poppy, please, just tell me what you want.
Then you still love me?
Yes.  Yes, of course it is.
Look at me, Icarus!  Look at my body.  I've done everything, changed anything you asked me to.  'We will always love most that which we create.'  Is that still true?
Icarus, please!  This is important!
Why are there two ottomans?
You know how I feel about you.  You know how much I need you.  How much I trust you.  I would do anything for you.
No, Icky, this is real.
Poppy, are you in one of your moods again?
She must feel something for him. After all, she and I did create him.
Do you think she loves him?
Based on what we know of him, that would seem inevitable.

That remains to be seen.

Dr. Nebbleman, I want to know the moment the nanobot arrives.  The instant, understand?
Gently, Ott.  Gently.
You're right.  Place a call to our friends at the network and to Mr. Joplin at the E.P.A.
A containment crew is going to attract a lot of attention.
Nebbleman.
Oh no.  No.  We'll get her assistant.  What's-his-name? Nebbishman?
In the meantime, we're going to need someone to deal with that mess in the lab.  I don't think we should call Dr. Bright.
Yes, that's true.  We have to find him, run tests, determine if the polymerization is stable.
You don't either.  We won't know anything until we find that guy and find out if he's alive or what.
But, Poppy, you don't know what this means --
Now, Icky, I don't need you winding yourself up.  I need you focused and in control.
It works, Poppy.  It works, it works!
Who cares!  We've got to find him! Hurry!
Icky!  What's happening?
Don't be a child, Icarus.  She is just another scientist and like all scientists, she doesn't care about anything outside the world of the laboratory.
She let it escape because she wants me to die.
She did not.  The mouse ran down the drain.
She's lying.  She lost the first one on purpose.
She says it's not.
It's ready now, I know it is.

No.  I'm getting used to it.
Icarus, please, if you want me to give you a bath just say so.
Oh no?  Smell this.
You're not rotting meat.
Like rotting meat.
Donated to science.  Perfect.
Wait, wait, can I at least have his body?

Thank you, sir.
Excellent work, Dr. Nebbleman.  You have outdone yourself.
Shut up and do it!
Of course you understand, Dr. Argon, that once the nanobot is inside of you, there is no going back --

Dr. Makeo is working on it now, sir. I estimate at least another six hours.
Excellent.  How long until the assembler tank is complete?
They're here!  They're here!  We have the nanobot.
The trunk.
Where did he go?
Dr. Nebbleman, take care of them.
She could have given him something to stimulate his kidneys.
Look, John, nobody wants to find out what happens.  That's why you're here.  We need your help on this one and that's why that suitcase is here.
Well, at this time, I mean that is to say, it is difficult to project --
Poppy, order the trucks from the Gary plant.  And we're going to need a containment crew.
That might work.
Then perhaps we can use liquid nitrogen to keep the meltdown under control.
Well, yes.  The replicators are not as active at low temperatures.
Facts, Dr. Nebbleman.  Facts. You've been using cryogenics to control the waste from the mouse experiment, haven't you?
Cleaned up?  It can't be cleaned up! Without the nanobot the waste can't be stabilized!  That's what we've been trying to tell you!  The only thing we can do is run!  Run!  Run!
The fact is, that the milk has been spilled and now we need you to tell us how to clean it up.
The nanobot is gone.

You don't want this.
Hey!

Oh no, no, no.  No can do.  You enjoyed a tasty beverage and thus this receptacle becomes your responsibility and I don't care if it's a Styrofoam cup or the Exxon Valdez!  You've got to learn to take responsibility!
Look, asshole, I don't got time for this.  If you got a problem, you better take care of it yourself.
I just want to know what goes on in the mind of a litterbug.  What chemical is secreted by your smooth brain that tells you, 'It's okay, just chuck it'?
You better quit pushing me, pal.
What is it with you litterbugs?  Is it a territorial thing, marking your turf with your garbage?
Why don't you just shove it up your ass!  Haw-haw!
Why don't you just put this in your pocket so when you see a garbage can you can put it where it belongs.
Haw-haw!  Why don't you run off and find a cop and I'll wait right here.
So what?  So what?  For starters, how about littering is a crime.
Yeah?  So what?
Make me?  How?  You think he's going to torture me?
I think that either you're going to give them to him or he's going to make you give them to him.

I'm a scientist.  I have lived my whole life by the diagnostic application of fact and the fact is, Argon is going to get whatever he wants, so if I were you, I'd give it to him.
Who isn't?
You're afraid of him.
Of course he is, but at least there isn't a security guard outside my door.
Nigel, can't you see he's using you?
No!  Well, not those exact words.
Is that what Argon told you?

Because I am a new man, Susan.  I am a man of vision.  Your problem, Susan, is that you're always looking down.  If you'd just look up you'd see the big picture and in the big picture men of vision do not dwell on what might be lost.  They focus on what can be gained.

Argon is a lunatic!  I can't believe I was stupid enough to believe I could control him.  You heard what he said, Nigel.  He doesn't care if all of Calumet City is turned to Jell-O.  How can that not affect you?
Dr. Argon would say we are all prisoners.
There's a guard outside my door! I'm a prisoner, Nigel!  Do you understand that?
Opportunity?
Susan, Dr. Argon is giving you an opportunity here.
I don't believe this is happening...

Dr. Argon, I know you want to use the nanobot on yourself, but you mustn't.  The situation is critical right now.  The replicators are growing exponentially.  If we wait much longer it will be too late. You have to use the nanobot to stop the meltdown.
Of course, sir.
You're looking for a urine sample.
You were never invited to my house.
What I've always done.  As long as I'm the only one who can build the nanobot, I'm the only one who can say when it should be tested.
What are you going to do?
I hope you're right.  I'd feel a lot worse if he had read them and just didn't care.
I bet he hasn't read a single report we've written on the waste problem.
This day just keeps going from bad to worse.
Worse.  Mrs. Argon wants to talk to you.  She's waiting in the lab.
The replicators?
Well, you got another problem.
They'll in validate the key. Probably nothing.
What did security say?
That's the guy?
Yeah.  But it wasn't a group.  It was one man.

Yeah, somebody broke in and stole the samples, one of those animal rights groups, right?  I remember now, they freed all the monkeys which caused that huge pileup on the Massachusetts Turnpike, right?
That's right.  C.D.C. found out and closed them down...
They also tried using viral R.N.A. as the bonding element.
Oh yeah.  They were working on molecular assemblers, too, weren't they?
Do you remember about five years ago, that uh... incident at Purnell Labs?
I'm not sure.  That's the funny thing about him.  He's the kind of guy that you never know what he wants or what he might do to get it.
What did he want?
Yeah.  I knew him when I was still in school.
A man?
This morning.  I saw someone I haven't seen in a long time.
Aaabout...?
What?  Oh, I'm sorry, Nigel.  I was just thinking...
Wellie well, Dr. Bright.  You're just in time.
Susan!
And if we evacuate, what do you want to do with O'Brien?
He's probably right, sir, the building is probably going to collapse under its own weight.
So, I guess it worked.
Sir, please try to hold still.
Yes.  That's it.  He's got it.  Oh God, he's got it!
Like Crazy Glue?
Smell?  Uh, something like methylcyanoacrylate.
What's it smell like?
Okay.
I've only been invited to her house once, but I know there is a basement lab that she uses for private research.
You want to tell me what I'm looking for?
Mr. Sim, watch out!  O'Brien escaped and could be on his way!
It's Sim.  We're almost there.
Yes?
I guess they do.
Things do change.

Do you suppose that was our problem? We met before our time?  I think that happens a lot.  People, events, planets all just circling each other waiting for that moment when everything clicks into place.
We were different people then.
God, what a fight that was.
I remember I was trying to help...
God, when we were in that store all I could think about was that one time, when we were in school, and you attacked that little kid who wanted some cereal.  Do you remember that?
Do the words 'hero fantasies' mean anything to you?  How about 'infantile dementia'?
I have to!
You're not going after Argon!
We don't have time to argue, Susan.
Daniel, just forget Argon.  Let's get out of here.  We'll find another way to stop the waste.
The same thing I suppose.
What would happen if I threw him into the core?
Yes.
That means the nanobot is still inside him.
You mean he's polymerized, like me?
It's too late.  Argon injected it.
We've got to get the nanobot.
Oh shit, the meltdown.  It's spread to the tower.
What in the...?

You don't have to say anything, Daniel.  I'm a scientist.  I know what's happening.  I recognize the classic symptoms.  Dizziness, shortness of breath, sweating palms... I can feel my adrenals secreting, my parasympathetic nervous system quivering, the estradiol coursing through my entire body...
Susie... I...
Did you think I could just leave you...?
You saved my life.
I'm not leaving without you, Susan!
Run, Daniel!  Get out of here!
Let's go.
Argon's private lab.
Where is it?
Oh no!  Argon!  We have to stop him before he uses the nanobot!  We have to get the nanobot!
What could happen?  I'm the plastic man, remember?
I didn't know what was going to happen.  I was just so worried something was going to happen to you.
You didn't think I could just leave you?
I don't believe it.  You're here! Oh thank God.
You're not going back to jail.  All we need to do is find the nanobot. Once the meltdown is under control, then we deal with Argon --
I can't go back to jail.  I gotta get out of here.
Oh no.  They're trying to blame you for the accident.  That means they must not have been able to control the replicators.
The head shrinker at the prison.
Who is he?
On the counter.
Did you go?
Sort of.  We used a process similar to the vulcanization of rubber and added bulk with a chain of chloroprene elastomers.
You made this out of my hair?
Like a glove.
That's going to fit me?
It's a crime fighting costume, what do you think?  It's underwear, so if you lose your clothes you'll still be decent.
What's that?
Getting used to it.
That's pretty good.
I was hoping you were over that. Remember to keep drinking fluids.
No cheese.
I think it would be better for me to go alone.  I'm sure Sim is looking for you.  Just sit tight.  I'll bring you back a pizza.
I could go with you.
Something else I want to try.
What did you want my hair for?
I'm going to go out for a while.  I want to take the blood samples to a lab that has the equipment I need.
I don't know.
How far can you stretch?
It's still inside me?
The nanobot... it's not here...
What's wrong?
Daniel, I didn't hear you come down...
Uh oh.  I remember that temper.
No problem.
Do you have something to bring me down?
Probably the caffeine.
I feel very emotional right now.  A bit out of control.
I'm glad you came to me for help.
I want you to know that I really appreciate you helping me.
Yeah.  Old times.
Just like old times.
And I don't see you sunbathing at Chernobyl!
Come on, I don't see you living in a cave!
But lo and behold he found another world that progress could annihilate!
And I'm sure you thought Columbus was going to sail off the edge of the world!
I don't consider uncontrollable toxic waste progress!
You're not protecting the world, you're obstructing progress!
This is what I deserve for trying to protect the world from a madman and his mercenary physicists?
Victim my ass!  You stole my security key and used it to break into my lab to do who knows what kind of damage!  Maybe this is the end of the story and you finally got what you deserved!
Blame the victim.
You have no one to blame but yourself.
Just giving credit where credit is due.
What's that supposed to mean?
Means?  Oh no.  We won't know what it means until the end of the story and maybe then it won't seem quite as funny to you, Doctor Frankenstein!
I'm sorry, Daniel, but you have to admit it's pretty ironic that you of all people would be the first man ever polymerized.  It's got to mean something.
Oh yeah, real funny.  Yuk-yuk. Let's laugh at everything a man believes in.
The polymerization probably synthesized into a kind of methyl- cyanoacrylate.  So what's wrong?
Just look at it!
What about it!
Look at this!
What?  What's wrong?
Susan!
No, no, I just feel wired!
Is something wrong?
No, why?
Lungs sound fine.  You didn't have any pre-existing physical conditions, did you?  Allergies? Infections?
You're the doctor.
I think while we're waiting, we had better run some basic diagnostics on you.
Isn't it already too late then?
That's right.
So right now there's little replicators spreading throughout Argon's lab?
With enough exposure, the same thing they do to everything else.
What do these replicators do to people?
Three days ago it was.
That was an egg?
What happens?
The replicators start off like assemblers, but the replicators never stabilize.
The waste.
The problem is the by-product created by the process.
Got it.
The nanobot combined your molecules with the plastic molecules in the white assembler fluid, so that on a molecular level you now have more in common with a Good Year tire than a human being.
That was 'simple'?

To put is simply, the nanobot inside you is a microscopic machine encoded with information like a strand of messenger R.N.A. that is programmed to synthesize your molecules with the polyisoprenes of the assembler fluid, rebuilding your entire organic system on a molecular level.
What waste?
The nanobot is the only thing that can stabilize the waste.
Why do we need it?
If you don't want to do it this way, I can remove it surgically.
Pills... you know how I feel about pills.
The nanobot is still inside you. It's programmed to exit through the urinary tract.  We need it as soon as possible, so swallow those.
Why?
Mostly caffeine diuretics.  Help you go to the bathroom.
What are these?
What has happened to you is nothing compared to what is going to happen to Calumet City if we don't hurry.
We don't?
We don't have time for hysterics.
I'm a plastic man!  A plastic man!
Daniel!
Oh God, please!  This can't be happening!  I can't be plastic!  A plastic man?!
Once the subject was polymerized we were unable to reassemble the original organic structure.
Oh no, no, no!  You've got to be able to fix me!  Please, Susan, tell me you can make me normal again!
Then you must have at some point tried to reverse the procedure.
Yes.
But you've polymerized single-celled bacteria and the fruit flies, I know you have.
It escaped from the lab before we could finish the experiment.
You don't know?
I don't know.
What happened to it?
My first organic-polymerization was a lab mouse.
Mouse?  What mouse?
... just like the mouse.
The nanobot.
They did it to me!
No, something is really wrong... look!
Sorry, Daniel, I'm a physicist, not a psychiatrist.
Please, Susan!  I need help! Something is wrong with me!
Daniel, what are you doing here?
Susie!  You gotta help me!
Susan, this is the future of America here.
Daniel, give him the Trix.
Am I?  Look!  Right there!  That's exactly what I am talking about.
You're insane.

You think it's a coincidence that they have all these aisles lined up like this, like a little maze! We're all lab rats running through their maze, pulling lever A or lever B, each designed to create some kind of bio-chemical dependency.  All the while they're everywhere, watching us, two-way mirrors, surveillance cameras, nodding to each other, making little notes.
I can't help it, Suze.  It's this place.  You know how I get in these stores.  They freak me out.  All these tiny boxes, little cans filled with eight syllable God knows what.
I'm sorry I brought the whole thing up!  If you're gonna flip your wig --
All I'm saying is that the companies that have money for the kind of research you're interested in, have money because that's what they're interested in!  Money!
We've had this conversation already, Daniel.

You think the chemists that invented Agent Orange twenty years ago were in school saying, 'Boy, I really got some good ideas for a highly toxic incendiary defoliant.'  You think Oppenheimer was dreaming about mushroom clouds before the war?
God, Daniel, I'm not going to make Agent Orange.
We'll see how wonderful it is after you spend the next twenty years making Agent Orange.
We'll see?  What does that mean?
Yeah, we'll see.

And what I love about molecular science is the way it revolutionizes how we have to think.  It unifies the entire world on a single level. Everything is completely connected. Sometimes I can really feel it, everything around us, just a small part of a whole.  It's really wonderful.
That's what I thought.
Nothing really worthwhile.
Sure.  Can I ask you one more thing? You haven't published anything in a while.  How come?
Well, it was good to see you, Daniel, but I have to be going.
Yeah.
It was a long time ago, Daniel.  We were young, different people, heading in different directions. That's all.
Do you ever wonder what happened to us, Susie?
Right.  You predicted it.
And for cleaning up oil spills.

Well sir, to be a putterer, one's mind must be at ease. A person with a problem could never be a putterer. For instance, sir, a fish can putter in water but not on land because he'd be out of place. An eagle can putter around a rugged mountaintop but not in a cage, because he'd be restless and unhappy. Now sir, if you will pardon me, with all due respect, sir, as a Smythe to a Smith, you are an eagle in a cage.
Well, if I couldn't be a good putterer, I wouldn't want to putter. But why? What makes you think I couldn't be a good putterer?
