Half the gunslingers that drift into town turn up on our police force.

J.T.'s done everything he can. I married a brave man. Augie, take that delightful gift your uncle gave you out of here while we're talking.  McKendrick picked the new sheriff himself, so J.T. can't even get the law enforced.
Let's get out of here.
New record.
I don't want you getting anyone in my place.
What's the matter, Paden? You afraid I couldn't get those two behind me?
That's what you said in Turley. You remember how that ended.
All I did was kiss the girl.
Get out of here, Jake.
Oh, a guy who got run out of town...
Who is he?
He is now.
This a friend of yours?
He'll be here.
Where's your brother?
We wait.
What now?
That's the longest I ever did it. 'Bout bust a gut.
Blind Pete taught me a great trick.
We didn't get that far.
Didn't he tell you about Blind Pete?
Right!
The other guy drew first.
Yeah, that's what happened with me too.
I've got no reason to run. It was a fair fight and there were plenty of witnesses.
Sure we are. We're leaving at dawn.
I can't say I'm convinced you're going anywhere.
You mean you ain't coming with Emmett and me?
Really?
You can't do this.
I'm done talking. Get out.
What are you talking about?
We're going to make some adjustments. I wanted you to be here when I offered Paden your job. I think he could do it without getting greedy. Stella and I are tired of you skimming our profits.
You wanted to see me?
Give the man a line of credit. He already owes the house thirteen bucks.
Howdy.
Kelly, get over here.  You didn't come all this way just to pay me back that money, did you?  Kelly, meet my friend Paden.
I decide what's right in this jurisdiction. Now move.
That ain't right.
You misunderstand. I want you out of town. In fact, I want you all the way out of my jurisdiction.
Is there a place in town that takes... my kind?

Came to the wrong town. I don't tolerate this kind of thing. It's hard on the peace, and it's hard on the furniture. Now, knowing a bit about Carter here, I'm going to let you go without paying for the damages. But go you will, and I mean now.
I wanted a drink and a bed. I guess I came to the wrong place.
There are three strangers in this room, traveller, and these gents you are accusing aren't them.  Are these your friends?
Don't press your luck, Carter.
Who's going to pay for all this, Sheriff?
Is that a fact?
We don't serve them here and you know it. I asked him to leave and he went crazy on us. He owes me money for this damage.
I don't like that word much, Carter.
This nigger's breaking up my place, Sheriff Langston.
What's all this then?
I was afraid of that.
Tomorrow morning. Ten o'clock.
So this is the guy you're going to hang?
The jury saw it differently.

But the good citizens of Turley have taken me in their embrace, and for one simple reason. I maintain the peace. So when strangers come to town, I always ask them their business. Have you come for the hanging?
You're kidding.
We'll see about that. I'm Sheriff John Langston. As you may have guessed, I am not from these parts.
We'd rather stay.
Now let's talk about you chaps.
Shut up. You need help, don't you?
Why him?
Because I'm your sister.
Why would they stop you?
What makes you think I could?
They're watching the Hollis place. I can't get through.
What's stopping you?
Because you're my sister. There's nobody else.  The men who killed Daddy are after Jake. I gotta talk to him.
Why come to me?
Rae, I need help.
Get out. We have nothing to talk about.
I don't have any family any more.
Rae, all we got is each other.
It's none of your business.
What are you doing here, Rae? This ain't for you.
Oh that's just fine. Where were you when Ma and Daddy needed you? It's too late, Mal. Now you finally show up and all you can think of is to get yourself killed.
I'm not sure, but I got an idea. And when I am sure, they're going to pay.
Who did it?
He was murdered.
Daddy's dead.
What are you doing here? I thought you were done with our family.
Hello, Rae.
Where's Emmett now?
Yeah, it's working out real good.
Lucky.
I got there just short of too late.
You don't know?
I heard from Stella you were trying to find Jake. What happened to Emmett?
Because they enjoy it.
Why are they doing this, Mal?
Good luck, Mal.
This is it, gents. My ma told me to head south past that rock.
Did you hear his son is still around?
I heard that too.
Things are getting messy around here.  I hear Ezra Johnson got himself killed.
We'll handle that. He's careless.
What about his brother?
He's good, all right. Too good for my men. That's why you've got to take care of it.
He must be pretty good.
Good-bye, Paden.
Yeah. Bad luck.  Good-bye, Cobb.
What a waste. This could have been such a sweet deal for us.
Not a thing. She's just a mutual friend.  But if you wind up on the wrong side of this, she's going to get hurt.
What's she got to do with it?
I'm not thinking about your future, Paden. I'm worried about Stella.
Cobb, you've got nothing I need.
I never could count on you to be reasonable.  Don't force me to make an adjustment around here.
I saw how you're putting Mal Johnson straight.
You gotta calm down, Paden. Everything will be put straight in a few days.
We didn't talk about this.  They took the little boy, Cobb.
I thought we talked about that.
Yeah, maybe I will too.
I'm going to have to look into this.
Don't worry about me. If you're taking on Emmett, the last place I want to be is between you.
So we understand each other?
I'm a great believer in doing nothing.
Nothing. Do nothing. Don't get between us.
What is it you want from me?

You know, Paden, what makes all this work is me doing my job. The fellows you came to town with are causing some trouble. It's going to take a little straightening out. I have my responsibilities. I want you to understand. It has nothing to do with us.
Well, thanks, but forget it.
Easy, boy. Just an idea.
Maybe you could run it without Stella.
It is that.
I told you this was a sweet set-up.
This is a lot of money.
I took out thirteen dollars.
Maybe we ought to ask Stella.
Nothing like that will happen between us.
You didn't tell me you owned a saloon.
Good old Paden. I was hoping you'd changed your mind about the job.
Luck, I guess.
What brings you into my saloon?
Stella, we still got an extra room out back, don't we?
I just got to town.
You got a place to stay?
Well I'm real happy for you, Cobb. But I think I'll keep looking for mine.
This is mighty sweet, Paden. I think I finally found my place in the world.
You're right.
Yes, sir. You wouldn't believe it.
You've got a legitimate job.
So have I. I've got a legitimate job now. I can use a guy like you.
I've given that up.
Let's talk about that.  I'm looking for some men.
Appreciate the loan. I'm good for it.
Where's the dog?
It's been a while.
I see you're prospering without me.
Hello, Paden. How ya doing?
Hello, Cobb.
You better get in there with her until this thing is over.
I've got a place I can hide her.
He can't hurt me if he's dead.
I don't want you to get hurt.
How about you?
I'm ready for that.
I like your attitude. But it can be risky.
Some people think because they're stronger -- or meaner -- they can push you around. I've seen a lot of that. But it's only true if you let it be. The world is what you make of it.
Is that what he said? Well, he figured it okay this time.

Nah!  What's he got? This is a nice saloon, but there are other nice saloons. It's not the money. Not for you. Why can't I get ahold of it?  Cobb says there's no telling what you're going to care about.
You sure? Maybe that's the kind of friend I am.
If he didn't you'd never sit still while this was happening.
What makes you say that?
Cobb's got something on you, and it must be pretty good.
What do you mean?
What is it that I can't figure?
He left me.
Where's the dog now?
Give me some of the good stuff.
You really are a gambler.
Oh, yeah? How good?
That's the good stuff.
What's this?
I meant, seemed like a lot of whiskey.
I'm saving lives here. The straight stuff would raise a blood blister on boot leather.
Is this a fair mix?
Here he comes right now.
Who's the owner?
I don't own this place. The man who does stuck me with Kelly.
Why'd you go into business with him?
Yeah, aside from being a loud-mouthed, lying cheat, he's just the man I would have picked.
So-called?
That's Kelly, my so-called partner. He runs that side.
You see that fellow over there in the gray coat?
You wouldn't be needing any help around here, would you? Maybe with the gambling?
Me too. What's wrong with us?
It's the only place I'm happy.
You like a good saloon?
And I know what I'm talking about.
Thanks. That's what I call it too.
My compliments to you, Miss Stella. This is what I call a saloon.
I am. I'm always there, but I only shine at night.
Stella... Are you the midnight star herself?
Paden.
Stella.
I'll drink to that. Will you join me, Miss --
The world is what you make of it, friend. If it doesn't fit, you make alterations.
Nifty.
I run the place. What can I get you?
You work here?
He says he doesn't care about anything, but he does. There's just no telling what it's going to be.
From what I've seen, Paden doesn't care much about money.
I thought you two would get along.
I wouldn't worry about that.
It's an advance. We want him to know he's going to be happy here.
Oh, yeah, you two are going to get along fine. You got a lot in common.
That was my plan.
Stella, this is one of my oldest surviving friends. Treat him right.
No!!  I can prove it to you.  I'll take you to her.
We all know what happened.  In a fit of jealous rage you killed Simone and dumped her body off a boat she bought for you.
I am telling the truth.
Why don't you just come clean, Viktor?  Tell the truth.  You'll feel better afterwards.
It wasn't her body.  It was her body of work.
Can you tell us why you were disposing of the body of a woman who didn't exist?
Who?
But not everyone's imaginary, are they, Mr. Taransky?  I refer, of course, to Edith.
And this Mr. Hank Aleno who you talk so much about, a renowned failure, who also happens to be so conveniently dead -- perhaps the "man" you claim helped invent Simone is an invention himself?
Of course.
So, of course, you couldn't kill Simone because there never was a Simone.
Oh, no.  The fan club is real.  But they were worshipping computer code -- ones and zeros.
A fan club with a worldwide membership in the millions -- also bogus?
That's right.  You understand perfectly.  I will confess to fraud, not murder.

-- Forgive me, Mr. Taransky.  I'm just trying to understand.  All these films, TV appearances, magazine covers, internet interviews, publicity photos, snapshots from her childhood -- all fake.  This is fake, this is fake -- fake, fake, fake, all fake.
Good-bye.
I'm glad we talked.
Thanks.  This is my exit so, I --
Okay -- for you.
Christ --  Elaine, I know how it looks but...  ... it would mean a lot to Viktor if you'd go with him to the Oscars. If you won't do it for him, please do it for me.
Simone, I recognize the shirt you're wearing.  I gave it to Viktor on his birthday.
I don't know how many times I have to say this, Elaine, but Viktor and I are not in love.  I only make love to the camera.
We have a daughter together.  I just don't want to see Viktor get hurt.
It sounds like you still have feelings for him.
Exactly.  You're a household name now.  You're moving in entirely different worlds.  That's why I hope you're not toying with Viktor.
Damn --  Yes -- I --  -- I'm just a little tired. Listen, Elaine, Viktor and I -- it's strictly a working relationship.  We could never be anything else.  We're just so... different.
My God, are you alright, Simone?
I'm not --  He's not.
You don't have to protect my feelings, Simone.  I don't blame Viktor for falling in love with the most desirable woman in the world.
I want to reassure you, Elaine, there's absolutely nothing going on between Viktor and I.
I think he owes more to you.  But that's not important now.  I know what's going on between you two.
I can't imagine how you ever let a man like that go.  I owe Viktor everything.
No, I understand.  That's what I want to talk about.  I don't know if you know this, Simone, but Viktor and I were married once.
I'd love to stop somewhere but I'm late.  I'm on my way to see Viktor now.
No... it's life.
Don't look so glum, Viktor.  It's not a death sentence.
That sounds wonderful.  How do you feel about all this, Lainey?
I was thinking -- what about you and... "Simone" moving back in with me and Lainey?
Exactly.  Now that you have the studio behind you, we can really do things.
Why stop at one character when you can have a whole cast?
Don't thank us too fast, Viktor. You know what we have to do?
Thank you!  I don't know how you did it but thank you.
How can you bring that up at a time like this?
Can I see you later -- go away for the weekend?

No!  Whatever talent Simone has comes from me -- me!  Me!  I swear, as God is my judge.  You don't know what I've been through.  Tens of thousands of mind-numbing hours in front of that screen, nights without end, and look what it's cost me.  Why do you think I've been wearing these?  I may have done irreparable harm to my eyesight, and why?  To extract and refine the infinite nuances of a human being -- a human soul.  Don't you see?  I made Simone!
You're drunker than I thought.  Are you doing that again?

-- She's a figment of my own imagination.  I, Viktor Taransky, have perpetrated the greatest hoax, the greatest sleight-of-hand, sleight-of-mouth, sleight-of- sleight in entertainment history! And still no one appreciates me, recognizes what I've done -- even you.
How much wine have you had?
Who says that -- ?  -- Never mind.  You have to listen to me, Elaine.  Simone is thin air, pixels, molded by me from a mathematical equation.  I inherited it from a madman -- I can show you --
-- You just got lucky that she's loyal enough to stay with you. Maybe she's staying out of pity, who knows?  She certainly doesn't need you.  Some people even say you're holding her back.
-- No, no, I didn't trip over her. You don't understand --

Every actor is an invention, Viktor.  Don't embarrass yourself. No one's denying that you discovered Simone.  But it's like finding a diamond in the desert. Anyone can trip over it, but it's not the finder who sparkles.
I'm going to tell you a secret now, Elaine.  Simone is not a real person.  I invented her.
You?
Not if I don't let her.
Of course she will.  Her public will demand it.
No.  She'll never work again -- retire, never make a movie or a record, or appear ever again.
But you don't understand.  She'll always be there -- at some party, on some magazine cover, some song on the radio, up on some screen.
No, I will end my relationship with her -- totally.
Oh, Viktor.  You say that now -- because we're here, alone, like this.  But in the morning, you'd go back to her.  What man wouldn't?
No, there isn't.  There's nothing to her.

That's sweet, Viktor, but I couldn't let you do that -- make that kind of sacrifice.  It's strange.  I've stabbed people in the back, clawed and slept my way to where I am -- it goes with the territory -- but, for some reason, I can't betray Simone. There's... I don't know any other way to say it -- there's a goodness to her.
I would rather have you than Simone.  Believe me.
This is crazy.  Who am I fooling? I can't compete with Simone.  What woman can?
I want you back too, Viktor.
-- She already is.  Simone's not coming over, Elaine.  Not tonight, not ever.  I want you back, Elaine.
-- And she was positively glowing at the awards.  I should be going, she'll be here soon --
I know.  I know.  They'll say anything.
I just read somewhere --
Impossible.
I'm sure you'll keep her focussed. She's lucky to have you, Viktor.  Is she really having your baby?
Not quite.
Is Simone back to earth yet?
I suppose I could stay, just until she arrives.
About now.  Would you like a drink?
When is she coming over?
As a matter-of-fact I am.
Is it Wednesday?  It's Wednesday. How embarrassing.  I don't know what I was thinking.  With all the excitement lately...  Am I interrupting something?  Are you expecting company?
Elaine, it's Wednesday.
I can imagine.
She's lying down.  She's exhausted.
... Simone.
Lainey and I just wanted to congratulate...
My two favorite girls.
It's a crowded summer.  We need every photo-opp, sound-byte and column inch we can get.  Good night, Viktor.
Excuse me?  Start?
Yes, you do...  Anyway, tonight was a good start.
I do?
Whenever I compliment Simone, you take the credit.
Do what?
Viktor, do you realize you always do that?
Thank you.

Well, yes.  From a studio point of view, it would be better if Simone stayed single.  Anyhow, I thought she came across great tonight.  Intelligent, well informed, a natural.  And touching. She was spectacular.
No, of course not!  Why?  Would you care if we were?
Are you and Simone...  ... getting married?
No.
-- Viktor, are you with her?  Is she there?
Oh, yes.  Of course.  Don't I always?
I'd love to.  But aren't you supposed to meet up with Simone?
Elaine, what are you doing tonight? Would you like to go somewhere -- dinner?
Really?
She said you were very beautiful.
She was there.  She didn't by any chance happen to mention me?
I'll try.  Maybe live but remote. She'll never go to them.
Oh, make it live -- please, Viktor.
I'll tell you what.  I know how much this means to you.  I'll try to get her to plug the film.  I'm not promising anything but maybe she'll do a talk show -- taped.
You're so good to protect her like this.
She doesn't want pity.
Viktor, you should have said something.
The premiere was the first time I've convinced her to venture out and it just confirmed her worst nightmares.
-- I don't think that's necessary. I think it's perfectly clear.  I should have guessed -- it all makes sense now... it's why she never goes anywhere, never seen in public...
-- I can explain.
So, the secret's finally out, Viktor.
Not now.  She's emotional.  Her mother dies today.  Scene forty-two of "Good For Nothing".  It's not a good time.
-- It's starting to look like she doesn't support the film or you, Viktor.  If you can't handle her, I will.
-- We have to talk to her, Viktor!
-- You can't go in there!
That's true.
Everyone you know is lying.
Everyone I know has met her, Viktor.
Soon.  Soon.
I'd love to tell her myself.  When are you going to let me meet her?
Thank you.  I'll tell Simone you liked it.

Yes.  To be honest I never quite saw this film before -- maybe it's the way Simone is playing it -- but what it's saying about the illusion of permanence in everyday life, how that's the only way we can love -- I think it's really going to mean something.
You really think so?
I should fire you more often.  The film's looking wonderful.
Better late than never.
Maybe you're right.  Twelve years after your daughter's born you decide to become a father.
Who else?  It's always Simone's idea.
That's genius, Viktor.  Was that Simone's idea?
I got them to remove the reflection.  The mirror's metaphor -- to show how her character's inwardly dead.
Thank you.  What did you think, Lainey?
Stunning, Viktor.  The Hollywood Foreign Press is going to eat this up.
Viktor, I have a feeling.  One of my feelings.  There's something about her I don't trust.
Simone does not control my destiny.
Experience, Viktor.  I've seen this a hundred times -- young stars destroying the very people who discovered them.  I'm worried about you, that's all.  This woman -- she controls your destiny.
Elaine, talking to you now, not as Viktor, director, but Viktor, ex husband... what the hell happened to you?

Listen, Viktor... I want to talk to you now, not as Elaine, studio head, but Elaine, ex-wife.  Second ex-wife.  You got lucky this last time but you need to be careful.  We both know you wouldn't be making this overblown art film of you hadn't convinced Simone to be in it.
I'll walk you out.
Not today.  She's learning her lines.  You can also take cue cards and teleprompter out of the budget.
Which accounts for your percentage.  When do I get to meet this dream?

As I've tried to explain to you, Elaine.  Simone isn't like any other actress you've ever known. She's about the work and only the work -- lives for the work.  She wants all the money up there...  ... on the screen where it belongs. She'd work for scale except I know you only respect people you pay a fortune.
Well, shoot it on the last day.
Even the fall from the plane.
Even the fall from the plane?
No need.  She does all her own stunts.
There isn't one.
What about it?
Well, we have to do something about this -- "stuntwoman".
-- I guarantee she won't gain an once.  She's very disciplined.
Al least a contingency for wardrobe.  Any woman can go up a dress size.
I'll send you her resume.
She was in the theater?  When? Where?
She'll do her own.  Theater training.
Hair and make-up?
She'll drive herself.
Well, something has to be done about this budget.  It's completely unrealistic.  You allowed nothing for limousine service.
If it's on the page...
Really?  Oh, so she's really going to do all this nudity?
There aren't any.  If the filmmakers are happy, Simone's happy.  She considers herself an... "instrument".
Whatever.  I still haven't received Simone's script notes.
"Forever".
Viktor, we simply have to talk about "Eternity..."
Why not?
No problem.  Do you want to come in?
Sorry I didn't get her back in time.
She's my actor.  There are other studios, Elaine.  There's only one Simone.  Leave the press conference to me.
Viktor, it's my studio.
Out of the question.  A circus like that?
Don't be ridiculous.  I arranged a press conference.
As I say, she's... something of a recluse.  That's how she's able to stay so pure -- by isolating herself in her art.
Why not?
I don't know if that's going to happen.
I can't wait to meet her.
Almost right.

I don't have it on me.  Anyway, it means a lot.  Have you read the reviews?  They're love letters.  Listen to this one.  "Simone has the voice of a young Jane Fonda, the body of Sophia Loren, the grace of, well, Grace Kelley, and the face of Audrey Hepburn combined with an angel".
Don't thank me.  It was entirely Simone's decision.  Do you have Simone's check?
Viktor... I want to thank you for convincing Simone to sign with the studio.
Why?  Because she would never show up at something like this.  She's intensely private.
Why isn't she with you?
Good to see you too, Elaine.
Where is she?
Even if you find her, you know the problem with unknowns, Viktor.  If they're good, they get known.  And then you're back to sorting their candy... and worse.  I'm sorry, Viktor.
I don't need a star.  All I need is an actor -- I'll reshoot the part, cut out Nicola and replace her with a real actor.  A real leading lady.
They're yours.  But how are you going to finish it?  Without a star there's no movie.
So there's no problem -- I can have the rights, the negative too?
The picture's dead.
You can have everything -- office, car, assistants -- all I want is the picture.

I'm not taking away your daughter, just your deal.  You and I both know, after the divorce I kept you on for old time's sake, so you could still hold your head up in front of Lainey.  I called what's his name at Warner's.  He said he'd take a meeting -- in July.  I've fought for you Viktor...  You want to talk severance?
How can I?  Your last three pictures tanked.  The board is giving me hell.  No bankable star will work with you after this.  If you just compromised... a little.
You're not renewing my contract.
-- Christ, Viktor, look around. What do you think pays for all this?  This is about investment and return.  Those days in New York... that's... it's over.
Spare me.
Listen, Viktor, I have good memories of those days too -- but this isn't about that or you or me or some high-minded ideal.  This is business.
-- Illuminate hearts and minds with a ray of truth.
-- It's called a projector.

Well, I do remember why I started out in this business -- you seem to have forgotten -- working in New York with Cassevetes -- we were trying to do something important, shine a light in that darkened cinema --
You realize you're nostalgic for an era you weren't even born in?

We can hardly make a profit with them.  Up-front salary, back-end deal, perks, per diem, percentages -- They're mocking us, Elaine. We're at their mercy.  We always had movie stars but they used to be our stars.  We used to decide who would play what role. We told them what to wear, what to say, who to date.  When they were under contract, we could change their names if we wanted to -- more than once!
It's the truth.  Those 17 superstars are our insurance policy.  We can't open -- can't make a profit without them.
Please.
The public decides who's on that list.
Elaine, she doesn't have any children!  Don't you see?  We're being held hostage by 12 men and 5 women who someone somewhere has decreed are the A-list.
-- What's wrong with that?

-- I'll tell you why.  It is because Miss Nicola Anders, supermodel with a SAG card God's gift to cinema, has it written into her contract that all cherry Mike & Ike's be removed from her candy dish along with strict instructions that any room she walks into should have seven packs of cigarettes waiting for her three of them opened, that there be a personal jacuzzi within eighty paces of her dressing room, and that any time she travels, her nanny must fly with her first class.
-- I have a feeling you're going to tell me.
-- overseeing the most cherished movie project of my career, am walking around with a pocketful of cherry Mike & Ike's?
-- Viktor, that was Short Subject.
Not just any Mike & Ike's -- cherry Mike & Ike's.  Do you know why I, Viktor Taransky, two-time Academy Award nominated director --
Hmm... Mike and Ike's.
-- Do you know what these are, Elaine?
Difficult.  I'm difficult.
God, Viktor.  Why do you always have to make things so difficult for yourself?
Excuse us.
No!  You will not give in to that blackmailing bitch!
We don't need a name.  We'll cast an unknown.
Of course she is.  No other name is going to sign on now and risk offending her.
Right beside you.  I borrowed Viktor's car.
Where are you?
Well, here I am.  You look pretty today.  Red suits you.
Yes -- oh my, God.  Is that you, Simone?!  I've been wanting to talk to you.
Hello, is this Elaine?
Hello?
Listen to what you're saying, mom. Is there any evidence she is?
Lainey, there's no evidence that Simone isn't real.
-- We don't believe daddy because we don't want to believe we were taken in too.
Well, I --

I know it's embarrassing to admit it, mom, but when I think about it -- honestly, I haven't.  I mean, it feels like I have.  I know more about her than members of my own family.  She's even in my dreams. But I realized, going back through my diary, they were all TV appearances, near misses at parties, second-hand rumor, gossip on the internet.  I've never actually seen Simone up close, touched her, been in her physical presence.  Have you?
I mean really meet her -- in the flesh.
Of course.  What are you suggesting?
So you did meet her?
I know it as surely as you're sitting here, sweetheart.  She was the most vital woman I ever met.
Because obviously she existed, right?
God, it's so like your father.  Why can't people take responsibility for their actions anymore?  I can almost forgive him for killing Simone -- but denying her existence.  I can never forgive that.
Just a minute.
Let's go, Lainey.  There's nothing here.
It was a great show, Dad...
Thank Simone for the tickets.
Sometimes.  But, just when I think your father's changing for the better, I realize he's as self absorbed as ever.  He took the credit for Simone tonight.
Mom, do you miss Dad?

Otto, I don't like Thorkel any more than you do.  But he has got a point.
If you really apply yourself, you'll get an A next time.
Oh. Yeah.  Thanks.
The paper, my boy.  A solid B-plus.
I'll try. Thanks.
You never know.  Go get some sleep.
I don't think I'll be running into him.
Really.  I'd like to speak with him.
Luck.  The right place at the right time.
This photo you took of "Spider-Man" -
No, thank you.  I'm sure you've got your own problems.
Need any more help?
Only Octavius knows for sure.  And last time I spoke to him, he was on the planet Whiz-Bang.
Not a lot.  I saw inside of the Science Center.  What exactly happened?
How much do you know about it?
Caused by Doc Ock's experiment?
Fortean phenomena.  Anomalies in our so-called reality. Weirdness, my boy, and lots of it.
Really, Professor, I--
Pretty lame for such a smart kid.
Actually, I got this spider bite
Your dog ate it.
An extension on that astronomy paper?  Because, uh...
Peter, what can I do for you?
Hi, Professor.  What's up?
Mr. Parker.
Letterman show, NBC. We'll talk then.  Bye.
Why? It is a wrestling match, or
Good. We'll make it oral for now. Meet me at Rockefeller Center at six tonight.
No
I was hoping you'd call, babe. Look, you got representation?
Hello, uh, Mr. Reiss?  I'm-- I'm the guy who wrestled Hulk Hogan the other day.  The guy in the mask?
Oh-- I don't know-- thanks, Mr. Reiss, but--
Kid, you were terrific.  Max Reiss, novelty acts.  Was that judo or something?  Ah, skip it.  Question is, can you do it again?
I just gave-- yeah, sure.
Mr. Reiss-- I need a quarter--
Okay, kid. Call me tomorrow.
No.  No, I-- my aunt and uncle. Something's wrong  --  I need to make a phone call.
I asked if you felt like a drink--
What?
... a couple a drinks at Sardi's?
Yup.  Oh, here's your check, minus my commission.  Solid, solid novelty act.
So they're airing this tonight?
Nah.  The big mask was better.
Like it?
Where'd you get the clown suit?
No, no!  Not there!
Up here, Docky Ocky!
Sure, in the war.  Pull those cables--
Professor, you ever fly one of these things before?
I'm not so happy myself.
Spider-Man, be careful!  He's quite mad.
Phooey on that.
I see.  Well, Octavius won't get much further. They'll catch him and... put him away.  Sad.  He might very well have the truth.
No, but I've got this secret identity to worry about. I'll swing the rest of the way.
Do you... live around here?
Just drop me off here.
Loonytunes.  And yet...
Bonkers.
I listened to him talk of eternal truth and thought of the Bhagavad Gita, the Indian holy book-- "I am become Shiva, Death-- the destroyer of worlds."  Octavius was...
Forgive me if I don't feel too sympathetic right now.
A messianic complex is nothing new to Octavius. In  his universe, there's only one mind-- his own. It must be very lonely.
And blow up the universe just to prove he's right?  Bit egotistical, isn't it?
He'll try to finish his experiment.
The usual.  Heredity and environment.  What's the deal with Doc Ock?
Excuse me if I'm impertinent, but-- how did you become whatever it is you are?
Imagine how I feel.
Logic.  Lot 49 is the closest stockpile of SL 270--  I do feel foolish talking with a man dressed like a--
Yeah, just a lung full of New Jersey.  Lucky you showed up when you did.
You're sure you're all right.
Right.  Let's go.
Explain that some jerk in a mask and costume fought a mad scientist with four tentacles?
I sent for  the police.  We can explain.
We did not.
You must have shot off your mouth all the way from Frankfurt to here.
How did he ever find out about that ammunition train?
Plenty.
What's wrong with him?
They may. That's why I would keep my mouth shut.
They never caught on.
I wouldn't talk about things like that.

Don't let him kid you. Cagney couldn't have pulled a sweeter job.  All right, boys. We were waiting in the depot in Frankfurt, see? And there was an ammunition train coming through, the longest ammunition train you ever saw, see? So Dunbar gets himself in the men's room, see? Fixes himself a time bomb, busts open the window and just as the train moves out, lays the thing in there, see? So then, he comes out like nothing's happened and three minutes later you can hear it -- boom! Broke every window in Frankfurt. It was gorgeous!
Then we shall all zalute Feldwebel von und zu Schulz! About face!
Jawohl!
Is you all little Adolfs?
Jawohl.
Is you all good Nazis?
Jawohl.
Forget it. He'll be back here. They've got no proof.
I had to be the ham! I had to shoot off my mouth!
Don't worry. He'll be all right.
Where's Hoffy? Why don't we get any news about Dunbar?
Take some matches, see?  And a cigarette, see?  Tuck the cigarette in like this, see?  Now the cigarette keeps burning like a fuse, see?
What's the match gag?
Just pulled the old match gag, see!
Throws what? How could he have a time bomb?

There was that ammunition train in the depot at Frankfurt, see? So Dunbar gets himself in the men's room and fixes a time bomb, see? Then he waits until the train starts moving out, see? And one of the cars got the door open with some straw on the floor, see? So he throws it, see, and three minutes later -- voom! See?
Do Cagney. Like you did yesterday.
He's still in the Kommandant's office. That's all I know.
Any news on Dunbar?
We made a deal with Barrack One.
I don't have to think. We didn't tell anything to anybody. Not a word. Not until we hit this barrack.
Maybe just a hint or so. Think hard.
Get going on the trap door.
Coming up.
Three's a crowd, especially if you've got to cut your way through barbed wire.  Here's the wire cutters.  Are the civilian clothes ready?
Okay. Move on.
Roger.
Ready?
Static!
Come on!
Looks good outside.
They ought to be under the barbed wire soon.
So long, Sefton.
So long, Cookie. The department store is all yours. What's left of it.
Yeah. Security.
If you don't want to tell me, why don't you tell Hoffy? Or Security?
Who is it?

That's not the point, Cookie. The point is what do you do with him? You tip your mitt and the Jerries pull him out of here and plant him someplace else, like Stalag Sixteen or Fifteen. Or you kill him off and the Krauts turn around and kill off the whole barracks. Every one of us. So what do you do?
Who is it?
Why not? Just one of the boys. Sharing our bunks. Eating our chow. Right in amongst the ones that beat me up. Except that he beat hardest.
In this barracks?

I understand how you feel, Cookie. It's sort of rough -- one American squealing on other Americans. Then again, Cookie -- maybe that stoolie's not an American at all. Maybe he's a German the Krauts planted in this barracks. They do this type of thing. Just put an agent in with us -- a trained specialist. Lots of loose information floating around a prison camp. Not just whether somebody wants to escape, but what outfits we were with and where we were stationed, and how our radar operates. Could be, couldn't it?
I don't know anymore.
What's the matter? You on their team now? You think I'm the guy?
We'll get some more.
There's only one pair left.
That'll do.
W-w-will that do or do you want some m-m-m --?
Forget it.
Brother, were we all wet about you!
We're looking at it.
Here's the knife to do it with. Only make sure you got the right throat.
No? Aren't you a little afraid to turn the stoolie loose on that compound? For a tip-off like this, you know what the Krauts would pay?
You ain't going to squeal this one, brother.
I wouldn't worry about Schulz. I'd worry about Sefton. Remember me? I'm the stoolie.
Thanks.
Have a cigar.
Why not?
Next we're going to auction off your department store -- and your stable.
Take it.
What are you looking at him for?  Any objections, Sefton?
You're all wire happy, boys. You've been in this camp too long. You put two and two together and it comes out four. Only it ain't four.
You make my mouth water.
Let's get on with what? What is this anyway? A Kangaroo Court? Why don't you get a rope and do it right?
Yeah, what about it?  Cut the horsing around. We know he's the stoolie and we know what the pay- off is. Let's get on with it.
A little something what?
And maybe a little something else?
I grease the Kraut guards. With ten percent of the take.
Ask Security.  You tell him, Price. You've got me shadowed every minute of the day. Or haven't you found out yet?
Just what makes you and them Krauts so buddy-buddy?
That's right.
I suppose they also know about your distillery and the horseraces?
Maybe it's going to be a longer war than you figured -- eh, Duke?
Static is right! The radio's static, Patton's static, we're static!
You stink, Sefton!

You would, would you? Listen, Stupe -- the first week I was in this joint somebody stole my Red Cross package, my blanket and my left shoe. Well, I wised up since. This ain't no Salvation Army -- this is everybody for himself. Dog eat dog.
A lot sharper, Sefton! I'd like to have some of that loot you got in those footlockers!
What's your beef, boys? So I'm trading. Everybody here is trading. Only maybe I trade a little sharper. So that makes me a collaborator.
Look, this may be my last hot breakfast on account of they're going to take away that stove. So will you let me eat it in peace?
Nice guy! The Krauts shoot Manfredi and Johnson last night and today he's out trading with them.
Forty-five cigarettes. The price has gone up.
Come on, Trader Horn! Let's hear it: what'd you give the Krauts for that egg?
How come the Krauts knew about that stove, Security? And the tunnel? How come you can't lay down a belch around here without them knowing it?
Private property, bub.
Anybody here wanna double their bet?
Hold it, Sefton. So we heard some shots -- so who says they didn't get away?
No crack. Two packs of cigarettes say they don't get out of the forest.
Now what kind of a crack is that?
Everybody but Joey, and you know who.
Then we're all in on it?
Only he ain't quite finished yet. Blondie -- get that smudge pot. Tie it to Steve's leg.
The S.S. Men are here to pick up Dunbar. They're taking him to Berlin. Looks like he's finished.
Easy! Walked right through the gate, past the guard. Like he was some Kraut Field Marshal.
How did he get over there?
There'll be no vigilante stuff. Not while I'm Barrack Chief.
How much more do we have to take from him?
Break it off!
You betcha. I said one of us is a stoolie. A dirty, stinkin' stoolie!
Come again?
Okay, Security -- what happened?
Don't ask me. Price was elected Security.
I'll call the whole pot.
Put me down for ten, you louse.
You are talking crazy!
That's the general idea.  Only it's not so general as far as I'm concerned.
Which one of you is what?
Come on, Schulz! Spill it! How did you get the information? About Manfredi and Johnson? About the stove and the tunnel? Who's giving it to you? Which one of us is it?
Tipping me off? I do not understand.
Cut out the guff, Schulz. We're on to you. You know everything that's happening in this barrack. Who's tipping you off?
Don't wear it out!
Such nice boys! It makes me sick to --
You killed them, huh? Both of them?
Let's!
Let's blow, Chauncey.
We'll know in forty seconds.  Only in a democracy can a poor guy get his keister shot off with a rich guy.
What are the chances busting out of here?
You won't get off that cheap.
It's on me.
Who doesn't! Suppose we wait until we hit the Waldorf Astoria.
Yeah.
What some brandy?
Not you.
What did you expect, a St. Bernard dog?
Sefton!
You'd better get that blue blood circulating, because we're busting out of this stink-hole in exactly --  -- one minute and twenty seconds.
My legs are frozen.
Shut off the moaning, or we'll have the dogs on us. Shut it off, Lieutenant. This is orders!
Look, Lieutenant. All your dough won't help you here. Because here you're on your own. And no mother to throw you a lifebelt. Now let's see how good you can swim.
Just a minute. You made a couple of cracks before and I let them slide. But I don't intend to take any more. If you resent my having money, start a revolution, but get off my back.
What did you expect, glamor boy? The Officers' Club with a steam room and a massage maybe?
They've got a summer house in Nantucket, with an upstairs polo field.  You better put a canopy over his bunk.
Twenty-five.

Maybe he would. We applied for Officers' Training together, remember? They turned me down, but I'm glad to see you made it. Of course, it couldn't be that all that dough behind you had something to do with it!  His mother's got twenty million dollars.
Yes, it would. Do we know each other?
Lieutenant Dunbar? It wouldn't be James Schuyler Dunbar? From Boston?
How could I have had a time bomb? They searched me when they took me prisoner.
Oh, come now! You threw a time bomb.
I didn't do it. I was in the Frankfurt station and the train was three miles away when it blew up.
You will remember the name? Von Scherbach? VON SCHER-BACH!
I want to sleep... I haven't slept for three days.

There will be two S.S. men here tomorrow to take you to Berlin. You will be interrogated by the General Staff. When you come to the part about your arrest, I'm sure you won't forget to give me the proper credit.
I didn't do it. I didn't do it.
Nine-thirty. General von Pfeffinger should be at his desk by now. Shall we call Berlin and tell him the good news?
I want to sleep. Give me five minutes on that couch.
You are being rude again.

Of course you did! Twenty-six carloads of munitions gone off like a trick cigar! The S.S. is running around in circles. The Gestapo is arresting the wrong people. And von Scherbach has caught the fish. Most amusing, isn't it?
I didn't do it -- I didn't do it.

You have no idea how boring my life here is. If it weren't for an occasional air raid or some foolish prisoners trying to escape, I wouldn't know what to do. I want to thank you for keeping me company. I don't drink, I don't smoke, I don't read. I hate music. That only leaves good conversation. It will be a shame to lose you.
Abfuehren!
Ever try forty sleeping pills?
No bother. I'm very grateful for a little company. You see, I suffer from insomnia.
I'm okay here. Why bother?
Of course you don't. Now, Lieutenant, how would you like to join me in my quarters? I have a nice fire going.
I don't know what you're talking about, Colonel.

Quite a transportation jam we are having outside of Frankfurt! They are very angry in Berlin. They will be even angrier on the East Front, waiting for that ammunition train. Don't you think so, Lieutenant?
I'll live.
That is correct.  Lieutenant Dunbar, I came to apologize for the accommodations. Ordinarily, of course, we never put officers up with enlisted men.
What is your number?
I am Lieutenant Dunbar.
How long is temporarily? I trust not until July.
The men here used it for a trap door, so we had to remove it temporarily.
What do you do for heat in this barrack? No stove?
They also smell of moth balls.  When were they issued? This morning?
As for the blankets, you will notice they are very warm. Fifty percent wool.
Naturally. It would be rather awkward to have three men in one bunk.
Here we have a typical barrack. It houses seventy-five men. Every one of them has his own bunk, naturally.
Perfectly all right. I do not like boots.
Very well. If you insist on details. I have ways of finding out about that blasted time bomb. Good day, sir.  You will forgive me for receiving you like this?
Isn't it?
Interesting.

Simply this. After the hostilities are ended, there will be such a thing as a War Crimes Commission. If this man should be convicted without proper proof, you will be held responsible, Colonel von Scherbach.
You were saying --?
I am not. According to the Geneva Convention --
All I know is he did it. I am satisfied.
And the way you search your prisoners, it does sound rather unlikely.
He is a prisoner of war until you can prove sabotage.
Whatever it is, it's out of your jurisdiction. This man is not a prisoner of war. Not any more. He is a saboteur.
What exactly is he charged with?
It is.
I want to talk about Lieutenant Dunbar. Is this Lieutenant Dunbar?
Well, Herr Inspector! How did you find the camp? Crowded but gemuetlich, shall we say?
And this?
It's a mouse trap.
What is this? This is water?
Raus! Raus! All of you!
Why don't we accept, Animal? The worst that can happen is we wind up a couple of lamp shades.
Droppen Sie dead!  Raus mit dem Ofen. Los! Los!

Hey, Schulz! I got a deal for you. Suppose you help us escape. We'll go home and have everything ready for you in Madison Square Garden. For the world championship! Schulz, the Beast of Bavaria versus Halitosis Jones!
You should live so long.
You always think I am a square. I have been to America.  I wrestled in Milwaukee and St. Louis and Cincinnati. And I will go back! The way the war is going I will be there before you!
Wisecrackers? Where did he pick up his English? In a pretzel factory?
Some are not bad at all.
Jawohl!
Ja -- ja! Droppen Sie dead! Always mit the jokes! Droppen Sie dead!
Then droppen Sie dead!
Jawohl.
Sprechen Sie deutsch?
Jawohl?
Say, Schulz --
Aufstehen, gentlemen! Please! You do not want to stay in bed on such a beautiful morning we are having today!
No. I want to draw.
You want to go?
Let me do it, Hoffy.
This is me, Animal! It's Harry Shapiro!
Betty! Betty!
Animal! Animal! Wake up!
I've been crazy about you for years. I've seen every picture you've ever made six times. I'd just sit there and never even open that popcorn bag.
Hey, Animal! Animal!
But it's not just those legs. It's that nose of yours I'm crazy about. That cute little button of a nose!
Why, sure!
May I have this dance, Miss?
There's a time in every man's life when he wants to be alone! So go away!
You don't want to cry over a dame that doesn't even know you're alive! Snap out of it!
It's that song, Harry!
You're crying, Animal.
Let me alone.
Come on, Animal -- let's trip the light fantastic!
I'll open mine, too.
I'll open mine now.
Animal! Got a little something for you!
There, Joey -- ain't that better than being a lawyer?
Hey, here's Esther Williams.
Do Grable.
Do Jimmy Durante!
Grable, not Gable!
Come on, you little stooge. Hand over them keys.
Why don't we just look in those footlockers?
You hold him. I'll slug him.
That Schulz pig. I'll get him yet.

This is a good one!  Shut up, everybody! Listen to this!  'The President of the United States to Harry Shapiro. Greeting: Having submitted yourself to a local board, you are hereby notified to report...' What do you know! So now I'm a draft evader!
Sugar-lips Shapiro! Frightening, ain't it?

So it is from the finance company. So it's better than no letter at all. So they want the third payment on the Plymouth.  So they want the fourth, the fifth, the sixth and the seventh. So they want the Plymouth.
Hey! This is with a typewriter! It's from a finance company!
It's not good for you, Animal.
That's what I wanna hear.
What do they always say?
What do those broads say?
Blind? How stupid can you get, Animal? I drank the stuff myself.
Harry -- I'm blind!
Bombs away!
She'll never forgive me!
To the Brick Kremlin!
Sharp. Sometimes I'm so sharp it's frightening.
You did?
It takes a gimmick, Animal, and I figured us a little gimmick.
How? Pinky Miller from Barrack 8 tried to get over there and they shot him in the leg!
Sure, Animal! I'll get you over there!
You'll fix me up!
Cut it out. Animal! I'll fix you up with a couple of those Russian women!
Not for me! Betty! Betty!
So what? There's other women!
Look at her! Isn't she beautiful! Married an orchestra leader!
You clocked him! Why don't I clock you?
I clocked him this morning. He was running like a doll.
Schnickelfritz! I told you Schnickelfritz! Why'd you make me bet on Equipoise!
Come on, baby! Daddy's going to buy you a hunk of cheese!
Equipoise! Equipoise! What did I tell you, Animal?
He's the grrrrreatest!
Wunderbar! Isn't he wunderbar!
He don't have to worry. He'll trade the Krauts for a six-burner gas range. Maybe a deep freeze too.
Ain't that too bad! Tomorrow he'll have to suck a raw egg!
Plant it, Animal, and grow us a chicken for Christmas.
Thanks. You're a real pal!  What're we goin' to do with it?
It's beautiful!  You goin' to eat it all yourself?
Don't you remember, Animal? A chicken lays those things.
Where'd that come from?
Easy, Animal! Easy!
No. Your eyeball goes. The top of your head. Gotta wind up with athlete's stomach.
No?
No, Animal.
Let go, Animal! It's chow! We'll miss chow!
You're teasing me again!
If she don't want you, she don't get anything.
Me? What if she don't want me?
What d'ya think, jerko! You're the award!
What's the award?

How? We go to California. I got a cousin that's working for the Los Angeles Gas Company. That's how we get the address, see? Isn't that clever? I take you up to her house and ring the doorbell and say, 'Congratulations, Miss Grable. We have voted you the girl we'd most like to be behind barbed wire with, and I'm here to present the award'.
Yeah? How you going to fix me up with Betty Grable?
Animal! When the war's over, remember I told you I'd fix you up with Betty Grable!
Betty Grable!
Let me go!
You want Betty Grable!
I don't care if they wear galoshes!
No you don't! You don't want any broads with boots on!
Who wants to eat? I just wanna get over there!
It's chow, Animal! Chow!
They'll shoot you, Animal!
Let me go! Let me go!
Lay off! The blonde is mine!
Hey -- Comrade! Over here! This is Harry Shapiro -- the Volga Boatman of Barrack four!
Look at me! I'm your baby!  Get a load of that blonde one! Built like a brick Kremlin!
Comrade! Comrade! Otchi Tchorniya -- Otchi Tchorniya!
Hey -- Russki -- Russki! Look at those bublichkis! Over here!
I said say it again. I didn't say repeat it.
I'm telling you, Animal -- these Nazis ain't Ko --
You can say that again!
I'm telling you, Animal, these Nazis ain't Kosher.
'We will remove the iron stove -- the one that was camouflaging the trap door.'
Let go, Animal! It's roll call! Hitler wants to see you!
I'll kill you, Harry -- so help me!
Hamburger and onions! Strawberry shortcake! Gefillte fish! Banana split! French fried potatoes! Chicken a la king!
Why do you do this to me every morning?
Coffee? Milk? Or how about a little cocoa?
Stop it, Harry!
Good morning, Animal! What'll it be for breakfast? Scrambled eggs with little sausages? Bacon and eggs sunny- side up? Griddle cakes? A waffle?
Maybe they were layin' for 'em out there!
Shut up, Animal!
Animal! Animal! Aren't you ashamed of yourself? A couple of guys are trying to escape and you're thinking of broads. Broads?
When you get going on those broads, think of me!
Curtains would do wonders for this barrack.  You will not get them.
Wait a minute. We have some rights here.  Why is this man being taken out?
Yes, sir.
...a Lieutenant James Dunbar?
You have a Lieutenant here...
Yes, sir.
Good evening, Sergeants.  A bit dank in here, isn't it?... Where is the Baracken-Fuehrer?

Of course. I'm aware of the Geneva Convention. They will be given the burial they deserve. Or perhaps you would suggest we haul in twenty-one cannons from the Eastern Front and give them a twenty-one gun salute?
Yes. According to the Geneva Convention, dead prisoners are to be given a decent burial.
Anything else?
As the duly elected Compound Chief, I protest the way these bodies are left lying in the mud.
Yes, Sergeant Hoffman?
Sergeant Hoffman from Barrack 4.
Because that's where he is. In the water tank.
Why the south latrine?
You'd better cut out in back of the south latrine.
What do you say, Hoffy. We'll hit the air raid trenches and cut out in back of Barracks nine.
Any objections, men?
I still say this is my tag. Any objections, Hoffy?
We've all done a poor job of it.
You have elected me Security. The way things have been going in this Barracks, I guess I've done a poor job and I want to make up for it. Is that asking too much?
No volunteers, Price. I said we're all in on it.
We'll take care of Schulz.  Come on.
What about Schulz?
Good.
Just as you say, Hoffy. But wouldn't it be smarter if I went out and kept Schulz tied up?
Maybe it's crazy, but it's better than having Dunbar dead.
I don't know what your scheme is, but it sounds crazy.
I want everybody out of here. We'll need a lot of commotion on the compound.
What are you going to do?
The guy I want to talk to is Sefton. Where's Sefton?  You haven't seen Sefton, have you?
It's not Schulz. It's that stoolie. Whoever he is, he's sure batting a thousand.
And don't blame me if you all wind up in the cooler.
Cut the horseplay, Harry. What's the matter with you guys?
Answer the question. How do you rate all those privileges?
Not yet.
Wait a second, Hoffy. Schulz says he's our best friend. Maybe he can give us a little hint.
You're wasting your time, Duke.  Outside, everybody! Let's get it over with.
Take some men and get the antenna going. Let's see if we can catch the BBC.
Don't worry. We'll take care of it.
Kill it, Duke. It's got us all spinning.
Look -- if you don't like the way I'm handling this job --
Come on, everybody!  Let's go!
You must get out. For your own good, you must get out.
The one you are hiding in the barrack, don't you know? The one your friend without the leg is smuggling all over the compound.
What radio?
One more thing, gentlemen. The Kommandant told me to pick up the radio.
We know! We got them last year. Five minutes after the Geneva Man was gone, the blankets were gone.
Yeah? How would you like to see the guts of nine pals splattered all over your plane?  C'mon Joey -- don't be afraid.
Sometimes I think he is fooling us with that crazy business.
Lay off, Schulz. He's got a sickness. He's krank.
Los, los. Dummkopf!
Check.
Let's synchronize the watches. Eleven forty-two, sharp.
You could use a new one yourself.
Shoot!

Price. When I go I want you to give me five minutes. Exactly five minutes to get Dunbar out of that water tank. Then you throw Price out into the compound, nice and loud. He'll draw every light from every goon tower. It's our only chance to cut through. What do you say, Barracks' Chief?
What's the decoy?
I told you boys I'm no escape artist, but for the first time, I like the odds. Because now I got me a decoy.
You betcha. There ought to be some reward money from Mama. Say ten thousand bucks worth.
You taking Dunbar?
Don't you know? Because I got my own ideas.  Let's have that civilian stuff.
What are we going to do with him?

He's a Nazi, Price is. For all I know, his name is Preismaier or Preissinger. Sure, he lived in Cleveland, but when the war broke out he came back to the Fatherland like a good little Bundist. He spoke our lingo so they put him through spy school, gave him phony dogtags --
Go on.
Uh-huh. Fell right on my head.  Sprechen sie deutsch?
You off your rocker?
You did!
Who did?
You told them, Hoffy.
How do they know?
I called it the last time, didn't I?
Look, Sefton, I had my hands full so they wouldn't tear you apart --
That's right. Or would you rather see Dunbar lying out there in the mud tomorrow morning like Manfredi and Johnson?
Hurry up on that trap.  What are you trying to do, Sefton? Gum up the works?
Anybody cover?
